FL 2274.jpg|300px]] |Ship caption={{HMS|Black Swan|L57|6}} in April 1945 }} {{Infobox ship class overview |Name=''Black Swan'' class |Builders= |Operators=*{{navy|United Kingdom}} *{{Navy|British Raj}} *{{navy|GER}} |Class before= |Class after= |Subclasses= |Cost= |Built range=1938–1946 |In service range= |In commission range=1939–1967 |Total ships building= |Total ships planned=42 |Total ships completed=12 (original) + 25 (modified) |Total ships cancelled=5 |Total ships active= |Total ships laid up= |Total ships lost=6 |Total ships retired= |Total ships preserved= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class= |Ship type=[[Sloop-of-war]] |Ship displacement=*1,250 tons original *1,350 tons modified |Ship length= {{Convert|299|ft|6|in|m|abbr=on}} |Ship beam=*{{Convert|37|ft|6|in|m|abbr=on}} original *{{Convert|38|ft|6|in|m|abbr=on}} modified |Ship height= |Ship draught= {{Convert|11|ft|m|abbr=on}} |Ship power= |Ship propulsion=*Geared turbines, 2 shafts: *3,600 hp (2.68 MW) (original) *4,300 hp (3.21 MW) (modified) |Ship speed=*{{Convert|19|kn|km/h|0}} (original) *{{Convert|20|kn|km/h|0}} (modified) |Ship range= {{Convert|7500|nmi|km|abbr=on}} at {{Convert|12|kn|km/h|abbr=on}} |Ship endurance= |Ship boats= |Ship complement=*180 (original) *192 (modified) |Ship sensors= |Ship EW= |Ship armament=*6 × [[QF 4 inch Mk XVI naval gun|QF {{Convert|4|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} Mk XVI]] AA guns (3 × 2) *4 × [[QF 2 pounder naval gun|2-pounder AA pom-pom]] *4 × [[Vickers .50 machine gun|{{Convert|0.5|in|mm|1|adj=on}} AA machine guns]] (original) *12 × [[Oerlikon 20 mm cannon|20 mm Oerlikon]] AA (6 × 2) (modified) *Depth charges 40 (110 modified) |Ship armour= |Ship notes= }} |} The '''''Black Swan'' class''' and '''Modified ''Black Swan'' class''' were two [[ship class|classes]] of [[sloop-of-war|sloop]] of the [[Royal Navy]] and [[Royal Indian Navy]]. Twelve ''Black Swan''s were launched between 1939 and 1943, including four for the Royal Indian Navy; twenty-five Modified ''Black Swan''s were launched between 1942 and 1945, including two for the Royal Indian Navy; several other ships were cancelled. ==History== Like [[corvette]]s, sloops of that period were specialised [[convoy]]-defence vessels, except that sloops were larger, faster, possessed much superior [[anti-aircraft warfare|anti-aircraft]] fire control via the [[Fuze Keeping Clock]] and a heavy armament of high angle 4-inch guns while retaining excellent [[anti-submarine warfare|anti-submarine]] capability. They were designed to have a longer range than a destroyer at the expense of a lower top speed, while remaining capable of outrunning surfaced [[German Type VII submarine|Type VII]] and [[German Type IX submarine|Type IX]] [[U-boat]]s. In [[World War II]], ''Black Swan''-class sloops sank 29 U-boats. The most famous sloop commander was Captain [[Frederic John Walker]]. His sloop {{HMS|Starling|U66|2}} became one of the most successful submarine hunters, taking part in the sinking of eleven U-boats. After the war, sloops continued in service with the Royal Navy, [[Egyptian Navy]], [[Indian Navy]], [[Pakistan Navy]] and the [[German Navy|West German Navy]]. In April 1949, {{HMS|Amethyst|U16|2}} was attacked on the [[Yangtze River]] by the Communist [[People's Liberation Army]]. Also, several ''Black Swan'' sloops fought in the [[Korean War]]. == ''Black Swan'' class == ===Royal Navy=== The first two ships were built under the 1937 Programme, being ordered from [[Yarrow Shipbuilders|Yarrow and Company]], Scotstoun, on 1 March 1939. The second pair was built under the 1939 Programme, being ordered from [[Furness Shipbuilding Company]] on 21 June 1939. A further ten RN ships were ordered under the 1940 War Programme on 13 April 1940; however six of these (the orders placed with White of Cowes, Thornycroft at Woolston, and Swan Hunter on Tyneside for two ships each) were subsequently replaced by orders for an equal number of {{sclass2-|Hunt|destroyer|0}} escort destroyers. There were incremental improvements as the building developed, and the ''Woodcock'' and ''Wren'' when completed were practically indistinguishable from the Modified ''Black Swan'' class. {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:97%;" |- !Name !Pennant !Builder !Laid Down !Launched !Commissioned !Fate |- |{{HMS|Flamingo|L18|2}} |'''L18'''
later '''U18''' |[[Yarrow Shipbuilders|Yarrow]], [[Scotstoun]]{{Harvnb|Hague|1993|p=76}} |26 May 1938]] |18 April 1939 |3 November 1939 |Transferred to [[West German Navy|West Germany]] as ''Graf Spee'' 21 January 1959. Sold for breaking up 25 October 1967. |- |{{HMS|Black Swan|L57|2}} |'''L57'''
later '''U57''' |[[Yarrow Shipbuilders|Yarrow]], [[Scotstoun]] |20 June 1938 |7 July 1939 |27 January 1940 |Sold for breaking up 13 September 1956. |- |{{HMS|Erne|U03|2}} |'''U03''' |[[Furness Shipbuilding Company|Furness Sbdg]], [[Haverton Hill-on-Tees]] |22 September 1939 |5 August 1940 |26 April 1941 |Became RNVR training ship ''Wessex'' on the Solent 4 June 1952, broken up October 1965. |- |{{HMS|Ibis|U99|2}} |'''U99''' |[[Furness Shipbuilding Company|Furness Sbdg]], [[Haverton Hill-on-Tees]] |22 September 1939 |28 November 1940 |30 August 1941 |Sunk by Italian torpedo bombers off Algiers on 10 November 1942. |- |{{HMS|Whimbrel|U29|2}} |'''U29''' |[[Yarrow Shipbuilders|Yarrow]], [[Scotstoun]] |31 October 1941 |25 August 1942 |13 January 1943 |Transferred to [[Egyptian Navy|Egypt]] as ''El Malek Farouq'' November 1949, renamed ''Tarik'' 1954. |- |{{HMS|Wild Goose|U45|2}} |'''U45''' |[[Yarrow Shipbuilders|Yarrow]], [[Scotstoun]] |28 January 1942 |14 October 1942 |11 March 1943 |Sold for breaking up 27 February 1956. |- |{{HMS|Woodpecker|U08|2}} |'''U08''' |[[William Denny and Brothers|Denny]], [[Dunbarton]] |23 February 1941 |29 June 1942 |14 December 1942 |Sunk by {{GS|U-256||2}} on 27 February 1944. |- |{{HMS|Wren|U28|2}} |'''U28''' |[[William Denny and Brothers|Denny]], [[Dunbarton]] |27 February 1941 |11 August 1942 |4 February 1943 |Sold for breaking up 2 February 1956. |} ===Royal Indian Navy=== Two ships were ordered under the 1939 Programme, the order being placed with Denny on 8 September 1939. The second pair were ordered under the 1940 Programme, this order with Thornycroft being placed on 29 August 1940. The first two were used as survey ships after the War. The second pair were transferred to the [[Pakistan Navy]] in 1948. The third pair (which were of the Modified ''Black Swan'' class – see below) {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:97%;" |- !Name !Pennant !Builder !Laid Down !Launched !Commissioned !Fate |- |{{HMIS|Sutlej|U95|2}} |'''U95''' |[[William Denny and Brothers|Denny]], [[Dunbarton]] |4 January 1940 |1 October 1940 |23 April 1941 |Survey vessel 1955. Paid off at end 1978 and deleted 1982 or 1983. |- |{{HMIS|Jumna|U21|2}} |'''U21''' |[[William Denny and Brothers|Denny]], [[Dunbarton]] |28 February 1940 |16 November 1940 |13 May 1941 |Survey vessel 1957. Renamed INS ''Jamuna'' 1968, paid off at end 1980 and broken up. |- |{{HMIS|Narbada|U40|2}} |'''U40''' |[[John I. Thornycroft & Company|Thornycroft]], [[Woolston, Southampton|Woolston]] |30 August 1941 |21 November 1942 |29 April 1943 |Renamed ''Jhelum'' 1948. Sold to be broken up 15 July 1959. |- |{{HMIS|Godavari|U52|2}} |'''U52''' |[[John I. Thornycroft & Company|Thornycroft]], [[Woolston, Southampton|Woolston]] |30 October 1941 |21 January 1943 |28 June 1943 |Renamed ''Sind'' 1948. Sold for breaking up 2 June 1959. |} == Modified ''Black Swan'' class == ===Royal Navy=== Fourteen sloops for the RN were in the 1940 Supplementary War Programme. The first two were ordered from Denny, Dunbarton, on 9 January 1941, ten more were ordered on 27 March 1941 (two each from Cammell Laird, Scotts, Thornycroft, Yarrow and John Brown), and a final pair from Fairfield, Govan, on 18 July 1941. The contract with John Brown was transferred to [[HMNB Devonport|Devonport Dockyard]] on 3 March 1942, and then to Denny on 8 December 1942. {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:97%;" |- !Name !Pennant !Builder !Laid Down !Launched !Commissioned !Fate |- |{{HMS|Chanticleer|U05|2}} |'''U05''' |Denny, Dunbarton |6 June 1941 |24 September 1942 |29 March 1943 |Constructive total loss following torpedoing on 18 November 1943 by {{GS|U-515||2}} (Henke). Renamed ''Lusitania'' 31 December 1943 as a base ship, then broken up at Lisbon 1945. |- |{{HMS|Crane|U23|2}} |'''U23''' |Denny, Dunbarton |13 June 1941 |9 November 1942 |10 May 1943 |Broken up March 1965. |- |{{HMS|Cygnet|U38|2}} |'''U38''' |Cammell Laird, Birkenhead |30 August 1941 |28 July 1942 |1 December 1942 |Broken up 16 March 1956. |- |{{HMS|Kite|U87|2}} |'''U87''' |Cammell Laird, Birkenhead |25 September 1941 |13 October 1942 |1 March 1943 |Sunk by {{GS|U-344||2}} on 21 August 1944. |- |{{HMS|Lapwing|U62|2}} |'''U62''' |Scotts, Greenock |17 December 1941 |16 July 1943 |21 March 1944 |Sunk by {{GS|U-968||2}} on 20 March 1945 just outside Murmansk, USSR. |- |{{HMS|Lark|U11|2}} |'''U11''' |Scotts, Greenock |5 May 1942 |28 August 1943 |10 April 1944 |Constructive total loss following torpedoing by {{GS|U-968||2}} off Kola Inlet on 17 February 1945; salved by Soviet Navy and added as ''Neptun'', finally broken up 1956. |- |{{HMS|Magpie|U82|2}} |'''U82''' |Thornycroft, Woolston |30 December 1941 |24 March 1943 |30 August 1943 |Broken up 12 July 1959. |- |{{HMS|Peacock|U96|2}} |'''U96''' |Thornycroft, Woolston |29 November 1942 |11 December 1943 |10 May 1944 |Broken up 7 May 1958. |- |{{HMS|Pheasant|U49|2}} |'''U49''' |Yarrow, Scotstoun |17 March 1942 |21 December 1942 |12 May 1943 |Broken up January 1963. |- |{{HMS|Redpole|U69|2}} |'''U69''' |Yarrow, Scotstoun |18 May 1942 |25 February 1943 |24 June 1943 |Broken up 20 November 1960. |- |{{HMS|Snipe|U20|2}} |'''U20''' |Denny, Dunbarton |21 September 1944 |20 December 1945 |9 September 1946 |Broken up 23 August 1960. |- |{{HMS|Sparrow|U71|2}} |'''U71''' |Denny, Dunbarton |30 October 1944 |18 February 1946 |16 December 1946 |Broken up 26 May 1958. |- |{{HMS|Starling|U66|2}} |'''U66''' |Fairfield, Govan |21 October 1941 |14 October 1942 |1 April 1943 |Broken up July 1965. |- |{{HMS|Woodcock|U90|2}} |'''U90''' |Fairfield, Govan |21 October 1941 |26 November 1942 |29 May 1943 |Sold for breaking up 28 November 1955. |} Another fourteen ships were authorised in the 1941 Programme, but the last three ships (the names ''Star'', ''Steady'' and ''Trial'' had been approved) were not ordered under this programme. The first of the eleven actually ordered was contracted with Thornycroft on 3 December 1941, with a further pair from Stephens, Linthouse, on 18 December. Eight more were ordered in 1942, two on 11 February, two on 3 March (originally from Portsmouth Dockyard), two on 12 August and two on 5 October. However the order for two sloops were ordered at Portsmouth was moved to Chatham Dockyard on 21 June 1943, and they were laid down there, but were cancelled on 15 October 1945. {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:97%;" |- !Name !Pennant !Builder !Laid Down !Launched !Commissioned !Fate |- |{{HMS|Actaeon|U07|2}} |'''U07''' |Thornycroft, Woolston |15 May 1944 |25 July 1945 |24 July 1946 |Transferred to [[West German Navy|West Germany]] as ''Hipper'' 9 December 1958. Hulked July 1964, sold for breaking up 25 October 1967. |- |{{HMS|Amethyst|U16|2}} |'''U16''' |[[Alexander Stephen and Sons|Alex. Stephen]], [[Linthouse]] |25 March 1942 |7 May 1943 |2 November 1943 |Broken up 18 January 1957. |- |{{HMS|Hart|U58|2}} |'''U58''' |Alex. Stephen, Linthouse |27 March 1942 |7 July 1943 |12 December 1943 |Transferred to [[West German Navy|West Germany]] as ''Scheer'' 1958. Sold for breaking up 17 March 1971. |- |{{HMS|Hind|U39|2}} |'''U39''' |Denny, Dunbarton |31 August 1942 |30 September 1943 |11 April 1944 |Broken up 10 December 1958. |- |{{HMS|Mermaid|U30|2}} |'''U30''' |Denny, Dunbarton |8 September 1942 |11 November 1943 |12 May 1944 |Transferred to [[West German Navy|West Germany]] as ''Scharnhorst'' 5 May 1950. Hulked 1974, and broken up April 1990. |- |{{HMS|Alacrity|U60|2}} |'''U60''' |Denny, Dunbarton |4 May 1943 |1 September 1944 |13 April 1945 |Broken up 15 September 1956. |- |{{HMS|Opossum|U33|2}} |'''U33''' |Denny, Dunbarton |28 July 1943 |30 November 1944 |16 June 1945 |Broken up 26 April 1960. |- |{{HMS|Modeste|U42|2}} |'''U42''' |Chatham Dockyard |15 February 1943 |29 January 1944 |3 September 1945 |Broken up 11 March 1961. |- |{{HMS|Nereide|U64|2}} |'''U64''' |Chatham Dockyard |15 February 1943 |29 January 1944 |6 May 1946 |Broken up 18 May 1958. |- |{{HMS|Nonsuch|U54|2}} |'''U54''' |Portsmouth Dockyard, later moved to Chatham Dockyard |26 February 1945 |colspan=3 align=center|Cancelled 15 October 1945. |- |{{HMS|Nymphe|U84|2}} |'''U84''' |Portsmouth Dockyard, later moved to Chatham Dockyard |26 February 1945 |colspan=3 align=center|Cancelled 15 October 1945. |} Two more sloops were authorised in the 1942 Programme; the names would have been ''Waterhen'' and ''Wryneck'' but they were never ordered in that year's Programme. The 1944 Programme re-instated these two vessels, as well as the twelfth sloop authorised under the 1941 Programme, and now named as ''Partridge''. These three ships were ordered on 9 October 1944, but they were all cancelled on 15 October 1945. These had been intended to be further modified and enlarged, with a beam of {{Convert|38|ft|6|in}}. Two further ships planned under the 1944 Programme would have been named ''Woodpecker'' (ii) and ''Wild Swan'', but these were never ordered and the intention to build was dropped when the 1945 Programme was compiled. *{{HMS|Partridge|U37|2}}, ordered from Thornycroft. *{{HMS|Waterhen|U05|2}}, ordered from Denny. *{{HMS|Wryneck|U31|2}}, ordered from Denny. ===Royal Indian Navy=== Two ships for the Indian Navy were included in the 1941 Programme, the order being placed with Yarrow on 10 September 1941. {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:97%;" |- !Name !Pennant !Builder !Laid Down !Launched !Commissioned !Fate |- |{{HMIS|Kistna|U46|2}} |'''U46''' |[[Yarrow Shipbuilders|Yarrow]], [[Scotstoun]] |14 July 1942 |22 April 1943 |26 August 1943 |Renamed INS ''Krishna'' 1968. Paid off at end 1981 and broken up. |- |{{HMIS|Cauvery|U10|2}} |'''U10''' |[[Yarrow Shipbuilders|Yarrow]], [[Scotstoun]] |28 October 1942 |15 June 1943 |21 October 1943 |Renamed INS ''Kaveri'' 1968. Sold 1979. |} ==Losses== ;In World War II: *{{HMS|Ibis|U99|2}} was sunk by Italian torpedo bombers off Algiers on 10 November 1942 *{{HMS|Woodpecker|U08|2}} was seriously damaged by an acoustic homing torpedo fired by [[German submarine U-256|''U-256'']] on 20 February 1944 whilst escorting convoy ON-224. The ship sank a week later on 27 February whilst under tow during an Atlantic storm. *{{HMS|Kite|U87|2}} was sunk by [[German submarine U-344|''U-344'']] on 21 August 1944 whilst the ship was escorting aircraft carriers covering the [[Arctic convoys of World War II|Arctic convoy]] JW-59. *{{HMS|Lark|U11|2}} was damaged beyond repair by [[German submarine U-968|''U-968'']] on 17 February 1945 *{{HMS|Lapwing|U62|2}} was sunk by [[German submarine U-968|''U-968'']] on 20 March 1945 just outside Murmansk, USSR. ==U-boat kills== *[[German submarine U-213|''U-213'']] was sunk east of the [[Azores]] by {{HMS|Erne|U03|2}}, {{HMS|Rochester|L50|2}} and {{HMS|Sandwich|l12|2}} on 31 July 1942. *[[German submarine U-124 (1940)|''U-124'']] was sunk west of [[Oporto]] by the corvette {{HMS|Stonecrop|K142|2}} and {{HMS|Black Swan|L57|2}} on 2 April 1943. *[[German submarine U-202|''U-202'']] was sunk at 00:30 hrs on 2 June 1943 south-east of [[Cape Farewell, Greenland]], in position {{Coord|56.12|N|39.52|W}}, by depth charges and gunfire from {{HMS|Starling|U66|2}} on 2 June 1943. *[[German submarine U-449|''U-449'']] was sunk north-west of [[Cape Ortegal]] by {{HMS|Wren|U28|2}}, {{HMS|Woodpecker|U08|2}}, {{HMS|Kite|U87|2}} and {{HMS|Wild Goose|U45|2}} on 24 June 1943. *[[German submarine U-462|''U-462'']] was sunk in the [[Bay of Biscay]] by a [[Handley-Page Halifax]] and {{HMS|Wren|U28|2}}, {{HMS|Kite|U87|2}}, {{HMS|Woodpecker|U08|2}}, {{HMS|Wild Goose|U45|2}} and {{HMS|Woodcock|U90|2}} on 30 July 1943. *[[German submarine U-504|''U-504'']] was sunk north-west of [[Cape Ortegal]] by {{HMS|Kite|U87|2}}, {{HMS|Woodpecker|U08|2}}, {{HMS|Wren|U28|2}} and {{HMS|Wild Goose|U45|2}} on 30 July 1943. *[[German submarine U-226|''U-226'']] was sunk east of [[Dominion of Newfoundland|Newfoundland]] by {{HMS|Starling|U66|2}}, {{HMS|Woodcock|U90|2}} and {{HMS|Kite|U87|2}} on 6 November 1943. *[[German submarine U-538|''U-538'']] was sunk south-west of Ireland by the frigate {{HMS|Foley|K474|2}} and {{HMS|Crane|U23|2}} on 21 November 1943. *[[German submarine U-119 (1942)|''U-119'']] was sunk in the [[Bay of Biscay]] by {{HMS|Starling|U66|2}} on 24 June 1943. *[[German submarine U-842|''U-842'']] was sunk by {{HMS|Starling|U66|2}} and {{HMS|Wild Goose|U45|2}} on 6 November 1943. *[[German submarine U-592|''U-592'']] was sunk south-west of Ireland by {{HMS|Starling|U66|2}}, {{HMS|Wild Goose|U45|2}} and {{HMS|Magpie|U82|2}} on 31 January 1944. *[[German submarine U-762|''U-762'']] was sunk by {{HMS|Woodpecker|U08|2}} and {{HMS|Wild Goose|U45|2}} on 8 February 1944. *[[German submarine U-734|''U-734'']] was sunk south-west of Ireland by {{HMS|Wild Goose|U45|2}} and {{HMS|Starling|U66|2}} on 9 February 1944. *[[German submarine U-238|''U-238'']] was sunk south-west of Ireland by {{HMS|Kite|U87|2}}, {{HMS|Magpie|U82|2}} and {{HMS|Starling|U66|2}} on 9 February 1944. *[[German submarine U-424|''U-424'']] was sunk south-west of Ireland by {{HMS|Wild Goose|U45|2}} and {{HMS|Woodpecker|U08|2}} on 11 February 1944. *[[German submarine U-264|''U-264'']] was sunk by {{HMS|Woodpecker|U08|2}} and {{HMS|Starling|U66|2}} on 19 February 1944. *[[German submarine U-653|''U-653'']] was sunk by a [[Fairey Swordfish]] from the escort carrier {{HMS|Vindex|D15|2}}, {{HMS|Starling|U66|2}} and {{HMS|Wild Goose|U45|2}} on 15 March 1944. *[[German submarine U-961|''U-961'']] was sunk east of [[Iceland]] by {{HMS|Starling|U66|2}} on 29 March 1944. *[[German submarine U-962|''U-962'']] was sunk north-west of [[Cape Finisterre]] by {{HMS|Crane|U23|2}} and {{HMS|Cygnet|H83|2}} on 8 April 1944. *[[German submarine U-473|''U-473'']] was sunk south-west of Ireland by {{HMS|Starling|U66|2}}, {{HMS|Wren|U28|2}} and {{HMS|Wild Goose|U45|2}} on 6 May 1944. *[[German submarine U-333|''U-333'']] was sunk west of the [[Isles of Scilly|Scilly Isles]] by {{HMS|Starling|U66|2}} and the frigate {{HMS|Loch Killin|K391|2}} on 31 July 1944. *[[German submarine U-608|''U-608'']] was sunk in the [[Bay of Biscay]] by {{HMS|Wren|U28|2}} and a [[B-24 Liberator]] on 10 August 1944. *[[German submarine U-385|''U-385'']] was sunk in the [[Bay of Biscay]] by {{HMS|Starling|U66|2}} and a [[Shorts Sunderland]] on 11 August 1944. *[[German submarine U-198|''U-198'']] was sunk near the [[Seychelles]] by the frigate {{HMS|Findhorn|K301|2}} and [[HMIS Godavari (U52)|HMIS ''Godavari'']] on 12 August 1944. *[[German submarine U-354|''U-354'']] was sunk in the [[Barents Sea]] by {{HMS|Mermaid|U30|2}} and {{HMS|Peacock|U96|2}}, the frigate {{HMS|Loch Dunvegan|K425|2}} and the destroyer {{HMS|Keppel|D84|2}} on 24 August 1944. *[[German submarine U-394|''U-394'']] was sunk in the [[Norwegian Sea]] by a [[Fairey Swordfish]] from the escort carrier {{HMS|Vindex|D15|2}}, the destroyers {{HMS|Keppel|D84|2}} and {{HMS|Whitehall|D94|2}} and the sloops {{HMS|Mermaid|U30|2}} and {{HMS|Peacock|U96|2}} on 2 September 1944. *[[German submarine U-425|''U-425'']] was sunk in the [[Barents Sea]] by {{HMS|Lark|U11|2}} and the corvette {{HMS|Alnwick Castle|K405|2}} on 17 February 1945. *[[German submarine U-1276|''U-1276'']] was sunk south of [[Waterford]] by {{HMS|Amethyst|U16|2}} on 20 February 1945. *[[German submarine U-1208|''U-1208'']] was sunk by {{HMS|Amethyst|U16|2}} and others on 20 February 1945. *[[German submarine U-327|''U-327'']] was sunk in the [[English Channel]] by the frigates {{HMS|Labuan|K584|2}} and {{HMS|Loch Fada|K390|2}} and {{HMS|Wild Goose|U45|2}} on 27 February 1945. *[[German submarine U-682|''U-683'']] was sunk by {{HMS|Wild Goose|U45|2}} and others on 12 March 1945. ===Reassessment=== *[[German submarine U-482|''U-482'']] was credited during the war to the ''Starling'', along with the sloops {{HMS|Amethyst|F116|2}}, {{HMS|Peacock|U96|2}}, {{HMS|Hart|U58|2}}, and frigate {{HMS|Loch Craggie|K609|2}}, as having been sunk in the North Channel on 16 January 1945. The [[British Admiralty]] withdrew this credit in a post-war reassessment in the 1990s.Blair (2000), 630–631. ==See also== *[[List of Royal Navy ships]] *[[List of ships of the Egyptian Navy]] *[[List of ships of the Second World War]] *[[List of ship classes of the Second World War]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Bibliography== *{{cite book|first=Clay|last=Blair|authorlink=Clay Blair|title=Hitler's U-Boat War: The Hunted 1942–1945|publisher=[[Modern Library]]|location=New York|year=2000|isbn=0-679-64033-9}} *{{colledge}} *{{cite book|last=Hague|first=Arnold|title=Sloops: A History of the 71 Sloops Built in Britain and Australia for the British, Australian and Indian Navies 1926–1946|year=1993|publisher=World Ship Society|location=Kendal, England|isbn=0-905617-67-3|ref=harv}} {{Refend}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Black Swan class sloop}} {{Black Swan class sloop}} {{WWIIBritishShips}} {{Frigates_of_the_Indian_Navy}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Black Swan class sloop}} [[Category:Sloop classes]] [[Category:Black Swan-class sloops| ]]
